peopleAlsoAsk.question: How to verify Native American artifacts?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: Having an official certificate from the IAGA will ensure the preservation of the artifact's provenance and historical information. The grade assigned, along with the classification, can be used to determine the approximate value and rarity of the artifact.
peopleAlsoAsk.title: Indian Arrowhead and Artifact Authentication

peopleAlsoAsk.question: How do you value Native American artifacts?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: Pricing your Native American artifacts The more rare an artifact is, the more valuable it is likely to be. Additionally, the condition of the artifact will also impact its value. Artifacts that are in excellent condition are typically more valuable than those that show signs of wear and tear.
peopleAlsoAsk.title: The Best Kept Secrets of Selling Native American Artifacts

peopleAlsoAsk.question: Who appraises Native American artifacts?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: Services provided by The Indian Artifact Grading Authority assist clients with establishing the authenticity, value and provenance of their Native American artifacts. Whether you are new to Indian artifacts or a lifelong collector, the IAGA will meet your needs.
peopleAlsoAsk.title: Indian Artifact Grading Authority

peopleAlsoAsk.question: How do I get my Native American rug appraisal?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: If local, call the Gallery for an in-gallery personal appointment. We will be happy to look at the item(s) and give you a free appraisal of your item(s) including both insurance and current market values. Call 800-579-0860 or 949-497-5747 to schedule an appointment.
